title: Clip black & white content using blending modes — Micro lesson #36
description:
Using blending mode in the Webflow Designer, you can clip out black and white content (such as text, borders, PNGs, SVGs, and more), so your content becomes a window to your background elements (this could be an image or a video).

If you have a white background and black content, choose the blending mode Lighten to clip out the black.
If you have a black background and white content, choose the blending mode Darken to clip out the white.

Check out the sites used in the beginning:
By Finsweet → https://webflow.com/website/NCC-Blending-Mode-Demo-2
By Threesixtyeight → https://webflow.com/website/Will-it-blend

Learn more about blending modes → https://university.webflow.com/lesson/blending-mode
Clone this project → https://webflow.com/website/Clipped-Text-with-Blending-modes-or-Webflow-University
----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

title: Introducing flex gap in the Webflow Designer — Micro lesson #32
description:
You can now use flex gap in the Webflow Designer. Similar to adjusting gaps in CSS grid, flex gap allows you to adjust the space between flex child elements without adding margin or padding. This is particularly useful for layouts where elements on a second row do not line up in columns with those on the first row.

00:00 - Introduction
00:12 - Problem with adding margin on both sides
00:50 - Using CSS grid to create a complex layout
01:19 - Apply flexbox & wrap children elements
01:31 - Use flex gap to adjust spacing between columns and rows

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: Here's a common layout issue on the web, and the spacing is ridiculous. Three cards, three div blocks, right next to each other. And since they all have the same class applied, I can add some margin to this. Nice. Here's the problem. Whenever I use margin like this, it invariably creates extra space on the sides. So what do I do? I get out my ruler, my scissors, and my opolar electric air blower. After that, I would create two combo classes. One to remove the right margin from the right card, and a second to remove the left margin from the left card. Yada yada yada, not the simplest form of web development. What about grid? Grid is great for two-dimensional layouts like this. In other words, we can add a gap between the columns, or even between rows. However, when we have an interface like this, where stuff is wrapping to the next line, there are lots of ways to build it. Right here, I'm using CSS Grid. And when the three items on top aren't lined up with the two items below, we have to use linear algebra to calculate the column design to support this. Not ideal. Enter Flexbox. It's what's for dinner. It's also how I can create layouts like this. But align and justify them by controlling the styles on the parent element. Click. Click. This mouse isn't even connected. But notice how these zoom things are overflowing. That's okay. Because Flexbox also lets me turn on wrapping. Once we've done that, we can align the rows how we want. And with this parent element selected, I can take all the power of grid gap from CSS Grid and access it in my Flex controls. I can add a gap between columns. And I can add a gap between rows. No more having to undo margin math manually. No more grids that require vector calculus to develop. All because of Flexgap in the Webflow Designer.

title: Build and manage your client's sites using Agency or Freelancer Guest - Webflow Tutorial
description:
Agency or Freelancer Guest in Webflow allows your client to invite you to their Workspace as a guest so you can build and maintain their sites from there. You will have full design, DNS, and publishing access to any new and existing sites in their Workspace so when changes or updates are needed you can handle it without the need to transfer sites or share passwords.

Send your client a link to this other video to show them how to share their workspace and sites with you: https://youtu.be/zi2TlM4ZF0s

00:00 – Intro
00:36 – Transfer
01:39 – Invite
02:31 - Access

To learn more visit Webflow University → https://university.webflow.com/lesson/agency-or-freelancer-guest-role#client-guide
----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

All we have to do is go over and transfer. Now remember, once you transfer a site, you will no longer have access to it on your workspace. Well, if your client has a Veflacount, then once they accept the transfer, that site will now be in their workspace. Next, we'll need our client to invite us to their workspace as a guest. Now I'll show exactly how it looks on the client's site. To be really clear, this is not what the agency or freelancer will see, this is what my client will see. We also included a separate video, which you can share directly with your client that shows exactly how to do this. Okay, what does our client need to do? Our client will go into their webflow dashboard. Oh, look, there's the site I just transferred to my client. If they don't have a Veflacount, they'll need to create one. But from the dashboard, they'll go to workspace settings. And over in members, they'll have the option we can see right here, to invite an agency or freelancer guest. title: Webflow for beginners: Webflow 101
description:
This course is the ultimate place to learn the fundamentals of web design and development. In this course, you’ll learn how to create a fully responsive (and accessible) website homepage with a navbar, cards, a form, and so much more, all in Webflow. And, at the end, you’ll have the skills to develop your own beautiful and impactful sites.

Learn web development superpowers, build your own site along the way, and share your progress on social media with #Webflow101. Then get certified — take our Webflow 101 certification exam. Let’s get started!

title: Getting clients: Dealing with tough client questions — The Freelancer's Journey (Part 5 of 43)
description:
We'll take the concepts we’ve covered so far and prepare for our first scheduled client meeting. Watch the full course, in order, for free: https://wfl.io/freelancer-2

Steps in the video:
00:00 - Introduction
01:18 - Schedule meeting
03:10 - Prepare questions
06:02 - Plan answers

title: Know code or no-code? | Generation No-Code | Bonus episode - Timothy Ricks
description:
No-code and code are one in the same — it’s how we use them together that makes a real difference. Learn about why no-code is the more expansive way to develop your website in this bonus episode with web developer Timothy Ricks.

Enjoy the full experience by watching at:
https://webflow.com/tv/episodes/generation-no-code-bonus-1

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: So, no code and code can play really nicely together. They're actually one thing when you think about it, and it's just how we use them. So, one of the top questions I get whenever I release a site is people ask, well, that site was built with code. Is that really a no code site? You included some code in that, right? And my answer to that is basically, there's no such thing as a site that's built with out code. Every site is built on code. And the beautiful part about no code tools like Webflow is that it allows us to build code in a clean way where we're not having to think about the syntax or how to write it. We don't have to have a missing semicolon that breaks the whole site, but we still have to understand what the code is doing. And in my opinion, that's the hardest part. Is understanding the logic behind why something does what it does, not necessarily how to write it or not write it. Those things can be easily looked up in fact. So, when we use code on top of no code tools, it's really just expanding upon what the no code tools have already taught us. We're able to use that same logic and just add a little bit more functionality onto it that maybe wasn't possible, or maybe it was possible, and there's just a cleaner way to do it by using code. Sometimes using a little bit of code can save so much time. It's the fastest cleanest way to do that. So, why avoid it? It unlocks so much potential and so much power, and we can use no code tools to speed up our workflows. To make things really fast, to where we can really spend all that extra time that we would have had on advanced interactions, functionality, and custom features that improve the user experience across the board. So, no code and code can play really nicely together. They're actually one thing when you think about it, and it's just how we use them. So, you may be thinking, if I already know code, why should I use no code tools? And I hear stories all the time of developers trying Webflow, loving it, and making it their primary platform. So, no code tools really speed up all the initial groundwork that we would have to do. Anything from setting up a database, to setting up a form, these are all very tedious tasks that can be automated. And we rely on no code tools when we do that. It really speeds up the workflow to where we're able to start building even better things on top of it. We're able to worry about the little details that really matter and invest time in those and into the functionality to make a better product. Another thing you may have heard is that using no code tools, sometimes leads to messier, unclean code. And I've tried a lot of no code tools. Simple things like dragging in a div, I inspect the code, and all the sudden, there's all these settings in code that I didn't apply, like Flexbox and margins, and I'm like, why is this one here? It just won't a div with no styles. But when you drag a div into web flow or when you add a block of element, it's completely clean. There's not a single style when there, till you apply it, and it's only the styles that you want there, you can add your own code to on top of it to make things even more efficient, but the base of no code tools like web flow is completely clean and easy to use. So there's so many great resources for learning code. And for me personally, I used an app called MIMO, and it's a free app that you can basically acquisice you on CSS, JavaScript, we were able to understand all the basics. Also develop to free course on YouTube, called the jQuery course, where it goes through all the fundamentals of jQuery. No, jQuery is not dead. Webflow uses it, it's a super clean way to write code, and I highly recommend it if you're a web flow designer to check it out. I've also learned from other jQuery courses on YouTube that were great resources. W3 schools is another great resource for learning CSS. Anything you want to learn, you can go to Google, type it in, and there's going to be the best way or the cleanest way to write it will come up. Honestly though, the knowledge is out there. There's so many great places to learn, it's applying the knowledge that it becomes real to us. So I would just say tackle some things that are maybe a little bit out of your comfort zone. Take on a project in web flow, maybe it's a passion project or something that you're think, I don't know if I'll be able to do this. And once you start and you start looking it up, it's going to challenge you to a point where you're going to begin to learn, and that understanding is going to become real to you. More than any course or any other knowledge out there is when you're actually applying it. And the second thing I would say is find someone that can be your sounding board, that you can bounce ideas off of. I've been very fortunate at the agency I work for to work with a ton of great developers that any time I have a question and I can go to them, share something, and that increases my knowledge so much more. And it advances what would it take me most to learn, I'm able to learn in a couple minutes. And there's nothing like having a great mentor that you can bounce ideas off of that will accelerate your learning so much faster.

title: Adjust and quickly remove CSS properties in the Style panel — Micro lesson #33
description:
As you use the Style panel in Webflow to design your site, you'll see plain, amber, blue, and pink labels for your properties.  Plain label means no change, amber label means this change is being inherited by a combo class or from another breakpoint. Blue label means a change is made on the current breakpoint. Finally, a pink label means a grid child has specific sizing and layout properties.

On pink and blue labels, you can clear or reset those styles by clicking on the label itself, or you can hold down Option or Alt and click on the label.

When a label in the Style panel is amber, by clicking on it, you can see where that style is being inherited from.

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

Amber means it's inheriting a value here, and I can just click the label and see where it's coming from. But the moment I change it, boom, it's blue. Remove it by going in and resetting, now it's back to amber. And we can see it's inheriting from desktop again. By the way, you can always hold down option or alt on your keyboard and click a label to reset the property instead of clicking in. So plain means it's not a changed value. Amber means it's inheriting a style from somewhere else. And blue means I've actively changed the style on the current breakpoint. What about pink? Well, CSS Grid is special. Pink means it's affecting the currently selected grid shell, something that's a child of a grid. But not the whole class, meaning I can change these things one by one. title: Convert images to WebP in the Webflow Designer — Micro lesson #38

00:07 — Hand code your images

title: Welcome to the age of no code
description:
At Webflow, we believe that the future of code will be visual. Why? Because we believe in the power of code — but in its current state, code is inaccessible to many. A wall between creators’ visions and reality. We’re here to break down that wall.

Want to learn more? Check out https://webflow.com/no-code

NCC 2019: https://webflow.com/blog/announcing-no-code-conf

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: Today, the world runs on code. Every text you send. Every website you visit. Every screen you swipe. It's all driven by code. Code that only a fraction of the world can even understand. And that's a problem. Imagine if only one out of every 400 people knew how to write. Think how many world-changing ideas would have never seen the light of day. We'd be stuck in the dark ages. And when it comes to software development, we kind of are. So what if, instead of writing hundreds of lines of code to add new features to your website, you could just design them directly on your website? What if you could create the next world-changing product without writing a single line of code? That's the future for creators, and it's about to change everything. It's time to unleash the power of software development to everyone by making it visual. So anyone can harness the power of code to build a website, nap, or an entire business without actually writing it. At Webflow, we're doing exactly that. We're empowering creators to design, build, and launch amazing things. No code required. Welcome to the future of software development. Welcome to the age of no code.

00:32 – Boxes flow like a text document

But unlike this, content on the web can reflow. And the box model lets us clearly define how these things respond, how they wrap, how they reflow based on the space available. For dimensions, that's adding properties for width, and that's adding properties for height. For spacing on any box, we can add space inside the box. title: Add a play/pause toggle button on background videos — Micro lesson #37
description:
Background videos can engage site visitors or add a cinematic flair to your site  — but they can also be distracting or even harmful for people with cognitive disabilities, vestibular disorders, or motion sickness. It's best practice to give your visitors control over autoplaying videos. Now in Webflow, you can easily add a button to toggle pausing and playing all your background videos.

If you're replacing your image in your toggle button, be sure to add alt text to your images, so screen readers can identify what they are.

Read about it → https://university.webflow.com/lesson/toggle-play-pause-on-background-videos

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: Background videos are a great way to engage website visitors. The problem is, sometimes they can cause motion sickness or cypress sickness. A lot of this can cause distraction and even harm. Not to mention, anything that auto place requires a way to pause or hide or just stop something like this in order to be level A we can't complain. So I want to demonstrate this with a background video element. When I drag it in, there's two things to note. It's pretty boring as is, that's because I need to actually choose a background video. Once that's done, we'll give it a height of 100 v8. So it takes up the full height of the viewport. And then we'll drag in some content. I'm cheating and I already have a container with everything inside. But the second thing is really powerful. It comes by default with a play pause button. I can always talk of this over in element settings, but it works like this. If we look in the navigator, we can see that inside the background video, there's a little button here. And it has two states. This is kind of like the success and error states in a form. We can replace our images. We can change whatever. Here's an example where we replace with a custom SVG and even add it a backdrop filter and a border. All of this we can customize. And to access each of these states, we can toggle them from that same place over in element settings. And here's how it works. On the site, the background video auto place. But if I press the pause button, boom, video paused. Resume, it resumes. Now, if someone has reduced motion turned on on macOS or show animations in Windows toggled off, the background video won't play by default. And it'll just pause itself as it loads. This will also happen on a lot of mobile devices when limiting data. Keep in mind, if you do want to replace the image asset, make sure you click on the link. Make sure your alt text is still set. So it's navigable by folks using a screen reader. And unless there's a really good reason not to, making sure all background readers have a play pause button is a great way to provide users with critical control over how they interact with your site. So we strongly recommend always featuring a button like this. But that's the play pause button in a background video with me as the background video in the web flow designer.

title: How to delete Collections in the Webflow CMS — Micro lesson #35
description:
Have you tried deleting your Collection in the Webflow CMS and it wouldn't let you? Don't worry — Grimur's been there too. We've all been there. There are three different reasons why you can't delete your Collection: 1) Your Collection still has Collection items, 2) your Collection is being used throughout your site, or 3) your Collection is being referenced in a field in another Collection.

In this micro lesson, we'll cover these three reasons and how to solve them. By the end of this lesson, you'll know what to check and what to do when deleting Collections in the Webflow CMS.

00:00 — Introduction
00:24 — Delete your Collection items
00:42 — Unlink connections on your site
01:17 — Delete reference fields from other Collections
01:41 — Delete your Collection (finally)

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

title: Animate a custom call-to-action banner — Webflow tutorial

A call-to-action banner is a great way to indicate an announcement at the top of your site and encourage your site visitors to do something. You can place banners anywhere and style them however you like, but this lesson walks through the structure and animation of a typical alert banner in Webflow (as inspired by Apple.com) — one that slides out from under the navbar on page load. We’ll also show you how to animate the banner so it changes color after the slide animation.

title: How to reuse elements by creating components — Webflow tutorial
description:
Use components to reuse any elements in your project and speed up your design process. Almost anything can be made into a component. A change to one instance of a component will affect all instances of that component. You can set properties on a component so you have control over individual instances. And you can unlink individual instances of a component so that changes to it won't affect the others.

00:00 — Intro
00:38 — Create
00:50 – Reuse
01:19 – Edit
02:00 – Properties
04:14 – Unlink

To learn more visit Webflow University → https://university.webflow.com/lesson/components

Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

title: Fundamentals of Forms in Webflow – Webflow tutorial

title: How to nest components within components — Webflow tutorial
description:
With components in Webflow, you can reuse any element and all its child elements in your project to achieve speeds that rival Usain Bolt’s. How is this different from using classes? You’re not just changing the styling, you can add or reorder elements inside your component and that will affect all other instances of that component. You can also override content in all instances of a component, so changes in that component won’t affect the others.
Now, you can nest components within other components — just like “Inception” (2010). Except, instead of dreams, we’re going deeper into components. And with nested components, you can still customize content on every level, which is much more powerful than inception.

Prepare yourself as we cover:
00:00 – Introduction
00:58 — Nesting a component inside another component
02:03 — Why? How this is different than using CSS classes
03:33 — Text
04:48 — Links
05:26 — Visibility
05:54 — Inception — editing one instance or multiple components
07:39 — Recap

Learn more about Components in Webflow at Webflow University: https://university.webflow.com/lesson/components
----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

title: Our investment in Webflow University — Webflow Conf 2022
description:
Webflow University holds a special place in our hearts. Learn how the team approaches each lesson and article, and about our commitment to keep community at the root of it all.

Read our Webflow Conf wrap up:  webflow.com/blog/webflow-conf-wrap-up


----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: I'm a designer from Pinnacle Assurance in Denver, Colorado. I'd like to see if you can, what would you attribute the Webflow University to the rise of your success and the amount of investment you've been in addition to having one of the most approachable tech tools in the market today. Your university is just brilliant, really engaging and full of really useful informative tools that brings people to your style, the method, the delivery. It's all brilliant. I just wonder if you could talk a little bit about the investment in it and maybe is there a future for where it's going? I can take a while before you answer it. Can we actually get a round of applause for Webflow University and all the people who are welcome? Thank you. I mean the short answer I could just say Stacy. I actually think Webflow University has been a really interesting learning experience for us. For not only learning the right ways to teach something, because if you look at Webflow, I think if you look at the learning curve for something like a simple drag and drop web builder, it's like you drag your elements in and we realize when you try to put a button in the center of the screen and you don't know the principles of HTML, CSS, and you do that and it just goes, it chunks. It goes to the top left. You're like one of two things. One, this software sucks. It doesn't work. Two, I don't know enough to be successful and I'm frustrated and I'm going to go ahead and leave. So very early on we knew we needed to create some type of teaching to get people onboarded in a way that's like here's the principles of HTML and CSS. I think it could be successful. Then came the how. And I think the how actually started with Vlad and Sergi and Brian long before I got involved before I was a Webflow user before I agency's Webflow. And I think for us we just get bored pretty easily. We watch a lot of tutorials. We read a lot of documentation out there and very often it's long. Very often it doesn't get to the point. So I think what we look at for our documentation team, what we look at for our video team is how can we get to the point quickly and how can we make it interesting for people? The weird part is how we do it behind the scenes. And so if you put a camera on a camera on a camera or you talk to our documentation team so much of it occurs from us just trying to put ourselves in the shoes of someone who's going to get frustrated with this feature if they don't know how to use it. And then we work backwards from there. I think the other big key to this though is that there's this marriage between understanding that it's not just education. It's also community. So we look at education and community at Webflow as people are signing up for this tool. What can we do to make sure on day one moment one they have everything they need to be successful? And how can we show up to support them? How can they feel connected to others who might be going through the same thing? Or who might have been through that? They've been there. They've done that. How can we connect them with other communities, sub communities so they have the resources they need to be successful? In terms of investment, God, we really strongly believe in education and community at Webflow. We think community is the lifeblood. I don't know. And if you want to add to that, there's a lot there and a lot coming. Yeah, I think like honestly as a user as well, I think like many folks in this room have been deeply impacted by that kind of lonely moment when you're like, oh crap, this is really, I've said crap three times with us now. This is hard. It's hard to learn and to feel like you don't know what you're doing. And for a lot of people, I think that is a huge reason why Webflow University is so impactful. And why it's such a no-brainer when we think about investment is because it makes you feel like you're not alone. And it's very much so the first step. For so many people into feeling like they know people like McGuire and his humor already off the bat to being able to reach out and ask for help in our community. And I think when we think about education and community and really like when we think about investment there, it's really a lot of it's time. And it's time that doesn't feel like work because it's all focused on how we can make things easier. And the beautiful thing about that is that through community and through all the incredible comments and even questions like this, it reminds us why we're constantly working on that and those comments help us better understand where we can move next. So in the future, really continuing to lean on the community of what's that next step, what's the other places that we can start to invest in and maybe even co-create as we continue to think about our marketplace strategy and how we can be on our existing user base. Yeah, and I know you asked the question about what's coming next. There's some stuff we can't talk about. Stay tuned. So some exciting stuff. Thank you. Thank you.

title: Webflow Labs introduces the Figma to Webflow plugin
description:
The Figma to Webflow plugin lets you turn your static designs into clean, production-ready Webflow HTML and CSS.  If you're used to creating your designs in Figma and then building them in Webflow, this new Figma plugin may help supercharge your workflow.

https://webflow.com/figma-to-webflow

Install the Figma to Webflow plugin → https://www.figma.com/community/plugin/1164923964214525039/Figma-to-Webflow-(HTML%2C-CSS-and-Website)

Read more about the Figma to Webflow plugin → https://university.webflow.com/lesson/figma-to-webflow-plugin

Got feedback? Share it here! → https://webflow.circle.so/c/figma-plugin

00:00 — Introduction
00:54 — Install the Figma to Webflow plugin
01:45 — Build a side-by-side hero section in Figma
05:19 — Quickly make a responsive navbar in Figma
06:11 — Paste the design into Webflow
08:34 — Recap

View the Figma project used in this video → https://www.figma.com/file/jOgEmnsAjEK586wlz8RD08/Figma-to-Webflow-plugin-%E2%80%94%C2%A0Pocket-page-design?node-id=0%3A1&t=DMuOjiYXEWLPayOs-1

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

title: The box model for beginners web design tutorial
description:
The box model describes how layout works on the web. Unlike other design environments (like Photoshop or Sketch) that allow you to position elements anywhere in a given document, the web places elements in boxes that you control the positioning of to indirectly create layouts. In this video, we’ll discuss: 

1. The box model
2. How the box model facilitates responsive web design
3. Grouping boxes
4. Positioning boxes to create layouts

----------

Grow your freelance career in web design:
https://wfl.io/freelancer-course

Get started with Webflow:
https://help.webflow.com/courses/getting-started

http://webflow.com
http://twitter.com/webflow
http://facebook.com/webflow
text: This is a basic web page. It's plain, and we can obviously see it's made up of the heading, some filler paragraphs, a few images, and some allegedly small buttons. The box model is the simple idea that each of these HTML elements is treated as a box. You can imagine a boundary on each of them. These boxes sit next to each other and stack on top of one another depending on the properties we give them. It's helpful to think of web content, not like a PowerPoint slide where content is simply positioned wherever everything having a fixed width and height, but more like a word document, where content flows naturally from the top left of the page. That's the default on the web, too. Now at first, this might seem kind of rigid, but it actually gives us tremendous flexibility as we create layouts for all kinds of screen sizes and devices. They get again about PowerPoint. Looks okay on a wide screen like this. But what if we try to scale it down to a phone? Not great. Using CSS, we can style our elements each treated as a box to respond to all kinds of devices, their positions and sizing and spacing can respect each other, and that's great. The other great thing about the box model is that we can organize boxes inside of other boxes. This heading is a box. This paragraph is a box. That's a box box, a box box, a rock box, and of course, who could forget the box box? And since we've put all these boxes in another box, that box can be used to organize and style the boxes inside. Here's a practical example of a layout we might develop for the web. And since each of the elements inside are boxes, we can move and push content around using padding to affect the space inside of a box and margin to affect the space outside of a box in between that box and the boxes around it. The big takeaway here is that we can use these concepts to control the styling and the layout for each and every element.

title: Micah teaches Grímur in-page links and custom scroll speeds — Micro Lesson #11

title: Quickly wrap an element inside a div or link block in Webflow – Micro lesson #39
description:
Now in Webflow, you can wrap an element in a div or link block in seconds, saving you clicks and maximizing efficiency in your design workflow.

Quickly wrap an element in div by pressing Command + Option + G on Mac or Control + Alt + G on Windows. And to wrap an element in a link, press Command + Option + A on Mac or Control + Alt + A on Windows.

Read about it at Webflow University → https://university.webflow.com/lesson/wrap-element-in-div-or-link-block

----------

Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: I wrap all sorts of things with Dev blocks. I want this heading in a Dev. I want this text block in a Dev. I want this button in a Dev. Heck, I even want my coffee in a Dev. title: Introducing variable fonts in Webflow – Web design tutorial
description:
Variable fonts allow you to add multiple variations of a font with a single file, making it possible to create more dynamic and flexible designs on the web. With variable fonts, you can add new fonts to your designs in Webflow and control various aspects of the font, such as size, weight, and slant, using axes. Additionally, you can add transitions and interactions on hover and mouse move, allowing you to create even more engaging and dynamic designs. 

Overall, Variable fonts is a powerful way for web designers looking to create more flexible and dynamic designs.

00:00 – Intro
00:43 – Add
00:59 – Axes
01:25 – Transitions
02:05 – Interactions

To learn more visit Webflow University → https://university.webflow.com/lesson/variable-fonts
----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow

title: Basic math in the Style panel — Micro lesson #34
description:
Calculating exact values can sometimes be difficult when moving from one app to another or when working to lay out elements that are perfectly positioned. In the Webflow Designer's Style panel, you can use basic math functions and easier calculations to get your designs pixel perfect.

00:00 — Mental math
00:17 — Adding and subtracting in Webflow
00:43 — Mixing arithmetic in Webflow
00:53 — P.E.M.D.A.S.

Learn more on Webflow University: https://university.webflow.com/lesson/basic-math-in-the-style-panel

title: Small on purpose: Thriving as a Webflow solopreneur
description:
Successful independent freelancers often face pressure to scale their team and delegate work — and most traditional resources agree that this is the right choice. But what if it’s not right for you? 

In this session, Grace will dive into why she chose to stay small and the benefits it’s brought to her business. You’ll explore her journey to freelancing, how she manages work, and how to grow your business without growing the number of people on your team.

----------
Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2r7cVUW
Join the Webflow Community: https://webflow.com/community

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: Hello and welcome. My name is Grace Walker. I'm an independent designer and webflow expert working to build websites that are visually stunning and technically sound. My career has steadily been shrinking in team size since I started working. I started my career working in-in-house for a mid-size creative team for a very large government corporation. I then worked at a small studio with half a dozen team members and now I work on my own. When I first started freelancing, I thought that working solo would be a temporary stepping stone. When I got busy, the advice that I received from peers and media was constantly telling me that I had to hire other designers and team members in order to scale and grow my business into an infinite creative building an agency seemed like the only goal to pursue. But what if it wasn't my goal? I've made the choice to stay small on purpose and I believe that choice has been key for my ability to thrive as a webflow solo printer. I share this story not because I think that the agency model is wrong, but to help creatives understand that there are other options that can be right for them to build a creative career. Let's start with the obvious question, why stay small? For me, there are three key reasons. Simplicity, flexibility, and control. Simplicity. There is only so much energy in a day and only so many days that we get. I feel so lucky that I found something I love to do for work and I want to spend as much time and energy as possible getting really good at that thing. Stay small means I can focus on my craft without having to add extra energy for things like team meetings, direction, and management. I have simple goals and I want a simple life and stay small removes many of the complex parts of running a business. Flexibility. A primary reason I went freelance in the first place was to have more flexibility in my career because I only have to worry about my time and income. I can spend more time doing things that I love, like taking Mondays off to ride my bike in the mountains, taking extended breaks, or working from home when I want to. I also have flexibility in the type of work that I do. I can work solo, collaborate with other designers, contract for agencies, or create products of my own. I can also pivot easily when my clients need change and move quickly to help them reach their goals. Finally, control. I find relief in knowing that I'm in control of my career. If I want to make more money, that's on me. If I want to take a break, that's on me. If I made a mistake, that's only on me. Both in the wins and losses, I find relief in knowing that I'm in control of the direction, pace, and reputation of my business. Because I have limited capacity, this also means that I have great control in who I choose to work with. I never have to say yes to work because I depend on a certain quantity, but I can say yes based on the quality of the project and client. These reasons are at the core of my values for staying small. But how do I actually put them into practice? I think I could talk about this all day long, but right now I'm going to run through my top five tips to thrive as a web flow solo printer. Number one, wow, your clients. This is the core of where web flow comes into my success. This is my top tip because it really is the base for the rest. The pursuit of great work is the foundation for any successful creative career, solo, or otherwise. While in your clients means going above and beyond their expectations, web flow is so key here because it opens up so many more possibilities for designers. As a freelancer, I can design and build a fully functioning, beautiful website for a client, similar to what a larger team may be able to do with custom code, and I can often do it faster with more flexibility and control. For example, I recently had a client who moved their product launch up by two weeks and wanted to have their website live sooner than my initial timeline. Because I have flexibility in my schedule, I said, let's do it. I worked to build the site out and ensure it was live for their launch. My client was thrilled and I was happy that I could deliver something above and beyond their expectations. However, while in your clients doesn't always have to relate to your creative output, I strive to wow clients on even the more mundane aspects of a project like scheduling, communication, and content organization. Some examples of this could be following up every meeting with a clear action item list, providing a clear structure for content population, or simply delivering things when you said you would. While in your clients is possible because of the flexibility of working solo and the control you have to say yes when opportunities present themselves. Number two, celebrate your work. Honestly, I debated putting this first but you need work to celebrate, so I put it second. I cannot stress enough how important it is for creators to celebrate their work. Unlike at a studio or a large agency, there is no one else that is going to promote your work, strategize about publicity or submit to industry awards. This can be a really hard thing to get over. Some of the most talented designers that I know really struggle to share their work because they view it as boastful or egotistical or be a little bit cringy, but clients can't hire you unless they know you exist. Celebrating your work can look like sharing when you sign a new client, posting your latest build, talking about your process, or sharing testimonials from your clients. I recently shared a thread of websites that I built on Twitter. The post garnered over 130,000 impressions, 2,500 profile visits, and 9,300 engagements. While not all of my posts or your posts or any ones are going to have that kind of traction, when something resonates with people, it's a great way to get your name out there. The week after I posted this, I received 10 new inquiries for work, compared to previous weeks, which averaged about 2 to 3 each. I'd also like to add here that I think it's worthwhile to show up as yourself on social media, not as a studio or a nickname, but for me as Grace Walker. People want to work with people and getting to know you can humanize your work. I've found Twitter to be a great platform to share about work, but I know others prefer different platforms. Celebrating your work leads to more visibility, usually more leads, and more control over the work that you say yes to. Number three, be selfish. When you're starting out, you take on all of the work that comes your way. I definitely did this, but once you have a steady stream of projects, it's really essential to be selfish with your time. I started to realize this after the first year of freelancing that if I wasn't careful, my career was going to be swept in a direction that I didn't anticipate, simply because I wasn't prioritizing what I wanted, I was just saying yes to anything that came my way. Being selfish often involves a lot of reflection. What are my values? Does this project align with those values? If I say yes to this, what am I saying no to? I'll try to practice this often, and if I'm not excited about a project, even though I know I could do a good job, I'll say no. This could be due to the industry, the chemistry with the client, or just to kind of build that I'm not interested in. I also try to think about this from the client's perspective. A client deserves to work with someone who is excited about their project, and if that's not me, it's okay to say no. Being selfish allows you to cut complexity and focus on the work that you want to do. Number four, find complementary collaborators. Being a solo performer doesn't mean you've always have to work alone. Collaborating with other designers across disciplines that are complementary can open up opportunities for larger-scale work without scaling the number of people on your team. This kind of structure can also be ideal to really hone in on what you enjoy working on. For example, when I first started freelancing, I offered branding and web design and development and SEO. Through many projects, I realized that what I really enjoyed was the web design and development. I started to think consciously about how I could focus just on that aspect of a project, and I made connections with brand designers who are responsible for setting the strategy, creative direction, and foundational elements of a brand. Once they've completed the brand work, I jump in to execute the website design and development. They get to do what they love, I get to do what I love, and the client gets a hyper-focused team of creatives that excel at their part of the process. These kind of relationships are often more of a collaboration than an agency structure, and both parties can operate independently. By pairing back my offering and collaborating with other creatives, I can simplify my work to the elements that I excel at. Number five, build a support system. Something I wish I would have done sooner in my independent career is prioritize building a support system. I think of a support system like strong pillars that hold me up and help me be resilient. If one of them is weak, the others can take more of a load, but if none of them are strong, then I can't be strong. My support system looks something like this. Emotional well-being, physical health, community, and necessities. In my first year of freelancing, this support system was pretty non-existent. I thought that I had to do everything and be everything to everyone, and if I wasn't, I was a failure. But building supports in each of these areas has helped me become a stronger person and a better designer. I started counseling to talk through business and personal challenges. I prioritize movement, like running and cycling to take care of my body and prioritize and reinforce that I can do hard things. I started to become more active in the Webflow community online and made connections with other designers for critique and commiseration. And finally, I asked for help at home with things like grocery shopping, cleaning, and the mental load of running a household. I have a fantastic partner who stepped up when I realized that I really needed some more support here, particularly as a solo printer, building a support system gives you greater control of your work and life. The beauty in solo work comes back to my values. Simplicity, flexibility, and control. Staying small is a choice that I've made for now, but I have a long career ahead of me. Nothing is permanent. You work at things until they no longer serve you and then you adapt to the next challenge. Being independent allows me to hone in on my design skills and work at becoming great at what I do. If that ever gets boring, I can reassess. But I hope to continue to have as much fun as I'm having right now. And I hope that with this talk, you can take away some tangible tips to build an independent career and know that growing your career doesn't have to mean growing a team. Thank you.

Because I have flexibility in my schedule, I said, let's do it. I worked to build the site out and
ensure it was live for their launch. My client was thrilled and I was happy that I could
deliver something above and beyond their expectations. However, while in your clients doesn't
always have to relate to your creative output, I strive to wow clients on even the more
mundane aspects of a project like scheduling, communication, and content organization.
Some examples of this could be following up every meeting with a clear action item list,
providing a clear structure for content population, or simply delivering things when you said you would.
While in your clients is possible because of the flexibility of working solo and the control you
have to say yes when opportunities present themselves. Number two, celebrate your work.
Honestly, I debated putting this first but you need work to celebrate, so I put it second.
I cannot stress enough how important it is for creators to celebrate their work. Unlike at a studio
or a large agency, there is no one else that is going to promote your work, strategize about publicity
or submit to industry awards. This can be a really hard thing to get over. Some of the most
talented designers that I know really struggle to share their work because they view it as
boastful or egotistical or be a little bit cringy, but clients can't hire you unless they know you
exist. Celebrating your work can look like sharing when you sign a new client, posting your latest
build, talking about your process, or sharing testimonials from your clients. I recently shared
a thread of websites that I built on Twitter. The post garnered over 130,000 impressions,
2,500 profile visits, and 9,300 engagements. While not all of my posts or your posts or any
ones are going to have that kind of traction, when something resonates with people, it's a great
way to get your name out there. The week after I posted this, I received 10 new inquiries for work,
compared to previous weeks, which averaged about 2 to 3 each. I'd also like to add here that I
think it's worthwhile to show up as yourself on social media, not as a studio or a nickname,
but for me as Grace Walker. People want to work with people and getting to know you can humanize
your work. I've found Twitter to be a great platform to share about work, but I know others prefer
different platforms. Celebrating your work leads to more visibility, usually more leads,
and more control over the work that you say yes to. Number three, be selfish. When you're starting out,
you take on all of the work that comes your way. I definitely did this, but once you have a
steady stream of projects, it's really essential to be selfish with your time. I started to realize
this after the first year of freelancing that if I wasn't careful, my career was going to be
swept in a direction that I didn't anticipate, simply because I wasn't prioritizing what I wanted,
I was just saying yes to anything that came my way. Being selfish often involves a lot of
reflection. What are my values? Does this project align with those values? If I say yes to this,
what am I saying no to? I'll try to practice this often, and if I'm not excited about a project,
even though I know I could do a good job, I'll say no. This could be due to the industry,
the chemistry with the client, or just to kind of build that I'm not interested in.
I also try to think about this from the client's perspective. A client deserves to work with
someone who is excited about their project, and if that's not me, it's okay to say no.
Being selfish allows you to cut complexity and focus on the work that you want to do.
Number four, find complementary collaborators. Being a solo performer doesn't mean you've
always have to work alone. Collaborating with other designers across disciplines that are
complementary can open up opportunities for larger-scale work without scaling the number of people
on your team. This kind of structure can also be ideal to really hone in on what you enjoy working
on. For example, when I first started freelancing, I offered branding and web design and development
and SEO. Through many projects, I realized that what I really enjoyed was the web design and
development. I started to think consciously about how I could focus just on that aspect of a project,
and I made connections with brand designers who are responsible for setting the strategy,
creative direction, and foundational elements of a brand. Once they've completed the brand work,
I jump in to execute the website design and development. They get to do what they love,
I get to do what I love, and the client gets a hyper-focused team of creatives that excel at their
part of the process. These kind of relationships are often more of a collaboration than an agency
structure, and both parties can operate independently. By pairing back my offering and collaborating
with other creatives, I can simplify my work to the elements that I excel at. Number five,
build a support system. Something I wish I would have done sooner in my independent career
is prioritize building a support system. I think of a support system like strong pillars that
hold me up and help me be resilient. If one of them is weak, the others can take more of a load,
but if none of them are strong, then I can't be strong. My support system looks something like this.
Emotional well-being, physical health, community, and necessities. In my first year of freelancing,
this support system was pretty non-existent. I thought that I had to do everything and be
everything to everyone, and if I wasn't, I was a failure. But building supports in each of these
areas has helped me become a stronger person and a better designer. I started counseling to talk
through business and personal challenges. I prioritize movement, like running and cycling to take
care of my body and prioritize and reinforce that I can do hard things. I started to become more
active in the Webflow community online and made connections with other designers for critique
and commiseration. And finally, I asked for help at home with things like grocery shopping,
cleaning, and the mental load of running a household. I have a fantastic partner who stepped up
when I realized that I really needed some more support here, particularly as a solo printer,
building a support system gives you greater control of your work and life. The beauty in solo work
comes back to my values. Simplicity, flexibility, and control. Staying small is a choice that
I've made for now, but I have a long career ahead of me. Nothing is permanent. You work at
things until they no longer serve you and then you adapt to the next challenge. Being independent
allows me to hone in on my design skills and work at becoming great at what I do. If that ever
gets boring, I can reassess. But I hope to continue to have as much fun as I'm having right now.
And I hope that with this talk, you can take away some tangible tips to build an independent
career and know that growing your career doesn't have to mean growing a team. Thank you.

title: Reveal elements on hover — Webflow interactions and animations tutorial
description:
Learn how to reveal child elements when you hover over the parent using a hover interaction.

Link to article on Webflow University: https://university.webflow.com/article/reveal-elements-on-hover

Steps in the video:
00:00 - Introduction
00:21 - Hover in animation
01:54 - Hover out animation
02:55 - Affecting the other donuts
----------

Get started with Webflow: https://wfl.io/2KPhrjD

https://webflow.com
https://twitter.com/webflow
https://facebook.com/webflow
text: In this video lesson, we'll cover using a trigger element like this link block to affect the animation of its child elements, the hard icon, and the obscene donut prices. We'll do this in three steps. Building the animation used when hovering in, doing the same for hovering out, then applying it to all the different donut options. Let's start by building the hover in animation. We'll make the link block the trigger. In other words, with our link block selected, we'll make sure that on mouse over, when you hover over this link block, the animation is triggered. We'll play the animation we're about to create when hovering over this link block. Once we go to create this new animation, we'll give it a name, and we can begin animating immediately. Let's start by grabbing our heart and moving it to the left. We're simply making an action or a keyframe which moves the heart to the left. We also want to make sure this is the initial state. That this is how the heart will be positioned when the page loads. Let's do something similar for the price. With the price selected, we can set its initial state just like we set the initial state for our heart, except we're moving it to the right. And all we have to do after that is bring the heart and the price back into view. And we can do this on multiple elements at once. We're simply holding shift and selecting the second element. Then we'll write or control click to duplicate. For that animation, we want to move each of these back to the origin, zero pixels. And if we press the play button right now, it works. It just happens to be boring and linear. For the easing, let's choose something that'll smooth this out. We can also reduce the duration to make the entrance a bit quicker. If we press play now, it's starting to look a lot better. And if we go into preview mode, we can see that upon hovering in, it works exactly as we'd expect, except it only happens once. because we need to define what happens when we hover out. That's hovering in, let's do hovering out. So let's close out of the animation we just built. That was the animation we built for hover. Let's simply duplicate it so we can use it on hover out. And we can do that, we can duplicate it right here. Once that's done, we'll go in and configure. Let's start by renaming it. You can name yours whatever you'd like, no judgment. And essentially for the animation, all we're doing here is trying to move our elements back to their starting positions. So we can delete the last part of the animation we did before, because there's no reason to move anything to the origin. And for these two, we can select both at once and simply switch off initial state. That means they'll animate from wherever they are back to their positions that are set here outside of the link block. We can adjust the easing like we did before. And we can adjust the duration as well. So what does this mean? It means if we go over to preview mode, this works on hovering in. It works on hovering out. But right now, it only works on this one element. Let's apply it to the other donuts. How do we get it to work on the others? First, in both animations, hover in and hover out. With any of the actions or keyframes selected for each element, we can affect the class. This is important because we can also set it to affect children of the trigger. And that means this. When we trigger the link block by hovering over it, it's children, the children of that link block will animate. We want to do this on both animations. That means we'll have to go over and do it on the other one as well. And once we do, we can close out of the animation and make sure we're triggering these animations on all our link blocks, all the donuts. The result, we have an animation which works perfectly as we hover in and out of each link block.
